questions.text: A 65-year-old male with chronic alcohol use was admitted with complaints of unsteady gait, difficulty in seeing, and appears confused. Which vitamin is he deficient in? (FMGE JULY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Vit B1

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Wernicke's encephalopathy, characterized by the triad of global confusion, ophthalmoplegia, and ataxia (mnemonic GOA), is caused by a deficiency of Vitamin B1 (thiamine) and commonly occurs in individuals with chronic alcohol use.

Based on the clinical presentation, which color-coded STI kit would you suggest for the following symptoms? (INICET MAY 2021)

questions.text: Which of the following hormones use receptor tyrosine kinase signaling? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Insulin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Insulin uniquely uses receptor tyrosine kinase signaling among the options listed, activating complex pathways that are essential for regulating glucose metabolism and other metabolic processes in the body.

questions.text: A baby assessed 5 minutes after birth is found to be pink, with blue extremities, and irregular respiration. Heart rate is 80 beats per minute. There is grimace and some flexion. What is the Apgar score for this baby? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 5

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Apgar score is used to quickly assess the overall health of a newborn, with a score of 5 indicating the need for some medical intervention but not immediate resuscitation.

questions.text: What is the likely diagnosis for a 34-year-old experiencing headaches, palpitations, and episodic hypertension?
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Pheochromocytoma

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The classic triad of headaches, palpitations, and episodic hypertension is strongly suggestive of pheochromocytoma, a condition characterized by the excessive release of catecholamines (e.g., norepinephrine) from a tumor, typically originating in the adrenal gland.

questions.text: Which of the following statements regarding MgSO 4 is false? (INICET MAY 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: MgSO 4 causes uterine relaxation, but is dose dependent

options.label: B
options.text: MgSO 4 is continued upto 24 hours after delivery or last attack of seizure

options.label: C
options.text: It has inhibitory effect on cerebral cortex thereby preventing seizures and lowering the BP

options.label: D
options.text: In renal failure, MgSO4 loading dose can be given, but maintenance dose should be adjusted based on renal function

questions.correct_answer: C. It has inhibitory effect on cerebral cortex thereby preventing seizures and lowering the BP
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) It has inhibitory effect on cerebral cortex thereby preventing seizures and lowering the BP

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ MgSO4 is used for preventing seizures in eclampsia and causes uterine relaxation but does not lower blood pressure.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1867, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1867, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: A pregnant woman presents with obstructed labor and is grossly dehydrated. Investigations reveal fetal demise. What will be the management? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Cesarean section

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Obstructed labor is a direct indication for an emergency cesarean section Obstructed labor happens when despite good uterine contractions, labor does not progress due to problems in the maternal pelvis/ fetus or a mechanical obstruction Features of Obstructed Labor: Maternal exhaustion and dehydration Abdominal examination Upper segment is tonically contracted with no relaxation The wall becomes thicker Lower segment becomes distended and thinned out Fetal parts not easily felt Round ligaments taut and tender Bandl’s ring is felt (Retraction ring) Fetal heart rate absent Vaginal exam Vagina feels hot and dry Cervix hangs loosely like a curtain Caput +++ Moulding +++ Head feels jammed in the pelvis The mainstay of management will be to start IV fluids and broad-spectrum antibiotics. Emergency LSCS is the rule in Obstructed labor even in a dead fetus
  • • Obstructed labor is a direct indication for an emergency cesarean section
  • • Obstructed labor happens when despite good uterine contractions, labor does not progress due to problems in the maternal pelvis/ fetus or a mechanical obstruction
  • • Features of Obstructed Labor:
  • • Maternal exhaustion and dehydration
  • • Abdominal examination Upper segment is tonically contracted with no relaxation The wall becomes thicker Lower segment becomes distended and thinned out Fetal parts not easily felt Round ligaments taut and tender Bandl’s ring is felt (Retraction ring) Fetal heart rate absent
  • • Upper segment is tonically contracted with no relaxation The wall becomes thicker Lower segment becomes distended and thinned out Fetal parts not easily felt Round ligaments taut and tender Bandl’s ring is felt (Retraction ring) Fetal heart rate absent
  • • Upper segment is tonically contracted with no relaxation The wall becomes thicker
  • • Lower segment becomes distended and thinned out
  • • Fetal parts not easily felt
  • • Round ligaments taut and tender
  • • Bandl’s ring is felt (Retraction ring)
  • • Fetal heart rate absent
  • • Vaginal exam Vagina feels hot and dry Cervix hangs loosely like a curtain Caput +++ Moulding +++ Head feels jammed in the pelvis
  • • Vagina feels hot and dry Cervix hangs loosely like a curtain Caput +++ Moulding +++ Head feels jammed in the pelvis
  • • Vagina feels hot and dry
  • • Cervix hangs loosely like a curtain
  • • Caput +++
  • • Moulding +++
  • • Head feels jammed in the pelvis
  • • The mainstay of management will be to start IV fluids and broad-spectrum antibiotics.
  • • Emergency LSCS is the rule in Obstructed labor even in a dead fetus
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Craniotomy : This is a destructive fetal operation which is not preferred anymore even in a non-viable fetus/ dead fetus. It can be done if ffacilities for immediate cesarean are not available. The main indications for fetal craniotomy are:
  • • Option A. Craniotomy
  • • Cephalic presentation with obstructed labour Hydrocephalus in a living fetus Interlocking head of twins Aftercoming head of breech
  • • Cephalic presentation with obstructed labour
  • • Hydrocephalus in a living fetus
  • • Interlocking head of twins
  • • Aftercoming head of breech
  • • Option B. Decapitation : It is severing of the fetal head from the trunk. It is a destructive operation and again is not preferred unless facilities for emergency LSCS are not available or in exceptional circumstances. Indications are
  • • Option B. Decapitation
  • • Indications are
  • • Neglected shoulder with a dead fetus Locked twins
  • • Neglected shoulder with a dead fetus
  • • Locked twins
  • • Option D. Forceps extraction : Instrumental delivery is contra-indicated in obstructed labor. CPD should be ruled out prior to applying an instrument (Forceps or vacuum)
  • • Option D. Forceps extraction

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of obstructed labor, an emergency cesarean section is the recommended management, even if the fetus is deceased.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 421, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 421, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8 th edition

questions.text: A 40-year-old male presents with increased thirst and increased frequency and volume of urination. He has no other symptoms. His random blood sugar was 205 mg/dl, what appropriate investigations should be done? ( INICET Nov 2023) HbA1c Urine ACR Echocardiography Fundoscopy ECG Serum protein electrophoresis
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) i, ii, iv, v

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For a newly diagnosed diabetic patient, essential investigations include HbA1c, urine ACR, fundoscopy, and ECG to assess glycemic control, kidney function, eye health, and cardiovascular risk, respectively.

questions.text: Identify the correctly matched pair of substances with their renal clearance from the graph given below? ( NEET PG 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: A - Glucose, B - PAH, C - Bicarbonate and D - Inulin

options.label: B
options.text: A - Glucose, B - Bicarbonate, C - Inulin and D - PAH

options.label: C
options.text: A - PAH, B - Inulin, C - Glucose and D - Bicarbonate

options.label: D
options.text: A - Inulin, B - Glucose, C - Bicarbonate and D – PAH

questions.correct_answer: B. A - Glucose, B - Bicarbonate, C - Inulin and D - PAH
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. A - Glucose, B - Bicarbonate, C - Inulin and D – PAH

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Understanding the renal handling of different substances such as PAH, inulin, bicarbonate, and glucose is crucial for assessing kidney function and diagnosing various renal disorders. Each substance's behavior in the nephron informs clinicians about different aspects of renal physiology, such as filtration rate and tubular function.

questions.text: Which of the following disease is exclusively seen in females? ( INICET May 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Rett syndrome

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rett syndrome is a rare genetic neurodevelopmental disorder almost exclusively seen in females. It is caused by mutations in the MECP2 gene located on the X chromosome. It is characterized by normal development for the first 6-18 months of life followed by a loss of purposeful hand skills, severe language impairment, and motor abnormalities.

References:

  • ↳ Reference: A Short Textbook of Psychiatry, 7th edition, Page No 165.

questions.text: A 5-year-old girl was washing her doll with shampoo containing rotenone. Her mother noticed her in an unconscious state. Which is inhibited by the above chemical? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Rotenone specifically inhibits Complex I also known as NADH CoQ oxidoreductase (NADH dehydrogenase) in the electron transport chain, blocking electron flow and ATP production.

questions.text: All of the following are criteria for diagnosis of DKA except: (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) S. Potassium < 3.5 mEq/L

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The diagnostic criteria for DKA include hyperglycemia, ketosis, and metabolic acidosis with an increased anion gap. Potassium levels, while important to monitor and manage in DKA, are not part of the diagnostic criteria.

questions.text: A 32-year-old married woman who came for the evaluation of infertility was found to have a septum in her uterine cavity. What would be the appropriate management of this case? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Hysteroscopy and septoplasty

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Hysteroscopy and septoplasty:
  • • Hysteroscopy and septoplasty:
  • • Uterine septum is a Mullerian anomaly where the uterine cavity is completely or partially separated by a septum. This can lead to infertility, recurrent abortions, preterm labor, fetal growth restriction, malpresentations, and retained placenta. The diagnosis of a uterine septum can be confirmed through hysterosalpingography (HSG), 3D ultrasound, MRI, or hysteroscopy. Hysteroscopy is the gold standard for both diagnosis and treatment. Hysteroscopic resection (septoplasty) is the appropriate management as it involves minimally invasive surgery to remove the septum, which improves reproductive outcomes.
  • • Uterine septum is a Mullerian anomaly where the uterine cavity is completely or partially separated by a septum. This can lead to infertility, recurrent abortions, preterm labor, fetal growth restriction, malpresentations, and retained placenta.
  • • The diagnosis of a uterine septum can be confirmed through hysterosalpingography (HSG), 3D ultrasound, MRI, or hysteroscopy. Hysteroscopy is the gold standard for both diagnosis and treatment.
  • • Hysteroscopic resection (septoplasty) is the appropriate management as it involves minimally invasive surgery to remove the septum, which improves reproductive outcomes.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Hysterectomy: Hysterectomy, the removal of the uterus, is not an appropriate management for a uterine septum in a woman desiring fertility. This would completely eliminate her ability to conceive and carry a pregnancy.
  • • Option A. Hysterectomy:
  • • Option B. Laparoscopy and metroplasty: While laparoscopy can be used to visualize the external uterine anatomy, metroplasty (surgical correction of the uterus) is better performed via hysteroscopy for a uterine septum. Laparoscopy is more invasive and not the first-line approach for this condition.
  • • Option B. Laparoscopy and metroplasty:
  • • Option D. Laparotomy and metroplasty: Laparotomy is an open surgical procedure that involves a larger incision in the abdomen. This approach is unnecessarily invasive for the correction of a uterine septum, which can be effectively managed with a less invasive hysteroscopic approach.
  • • Option D. Laparotomy and metroplasty:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The appropriate management of a uterine septum, especially in a woman seeking fertility, is hysteroscopic resection (septoplasty), which involves minimally invasive surgery to remove the septum and improve reproductive outcomes.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 47, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 47, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6 th edition

questions.text: Identify the true statement regarding the point marked on the myocardial action potential curve?(NEET PG 2023)

options.label: A
options.text: Due to opening of Na+ and closure of fast K+ channels

options.label: B
options.text: Due to slow but prolonged opening of Ca2+ channels

options.label: C
options.text: Due to closure of Na+ and opening of slow K+ channel

questions.correct_answer: B. Due to slow but prolonged opening of Ca2+ channels
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Due to slow but prolonged opening of Ca2+ channels

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Marked point on the myocardial action potential curve represents the plateau phase, which is due to the slower and prolonged opening of calcium channels.
  • • Two types of voltage-gated Ca2+ channels (T- and L-types) are present in myocardial cells. The opening of the slower L-type Ca2+ channels are mostly responsible for changes in the action potential. The action potential curve of cardiac muscles consists of 5 phases, as shown.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A : Incorrect because it mentions both the opening of sodium channels and the closure of fast potassium channels, which is characteristic of Phase 0, not the plateau phase.
  • • Option A
  • • Option C : Incorrect as it attributes the phase to the closure of sodium channels and the opening of slow potassium channels, which more accurately describes the repolarization phase (Phase 3) of the myocardial action potential.
  • • Option C
  • • Option D : Incorrect because the Na+/K+ ATPase pump, which helps maintain the resting membrane potential, is not the primary driver of the changes observed in the plateau phase.
  • • Option D

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: The following are the phases of: (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Demographic process

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Demography is the scientific study of human populations, and demographic processes are the key factors that influence population dynamics. The five main demographic processes mentioned in the image are:
  • • Fertility : Related to childbirth and reproduction Mortality : Related to deaths and life expectancy Marriage : Formation and dissolution of marital unions Migration : Physical or geographical movement of people from one place to another Social mobility : Movement of individuals across social classes or socio-economic status
  • • Fertility : Related to childbirth and reproduction
  • • Fertility
  • • Mortality : Related to deaths and life expectancy
  • • Mortality
  • • Marriage : Formation and dissolution of marital unions
  • • Marriage
  • • Migration : Physical or geographical movement of people from one place to another
  • • Migration
  • • Social mobility : Movement of individuals across social classes or socio-economic status
  • • Social mobility
  • • These processes collectively determine the size, structure, and distribution of populations over time.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Demographic dividend : This refers to the economic growth potential resulting from a population's changing age structure, typically when the working-age population is larger than the non-working-age population. It is not directly related to the five processes listed.
  • • Option
  • • B. Demographic dividend
  • • Option C. Demographic cycle: Also known as the demographic transition model, this describes the stages a population goes through as it transitions from high birth and death rates to low birth and death rates. While related to demographic processes, the stages of the demographic cycle are not the same as the processes listed.
  • • Option
  • • C. Demographic cycle:
  • • Option D. Human Development Index (HDI): This is a composite statistic developed by the United Nations to measure and rank countries' levels of social and economic development. It takes into account life expectancy, education, and per capita income. HDI is not directly related to the five demographic processes mentioned.
  • • Option
  • • D. Human Development Index (HDI):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Fertility, mortality, marriage, migration, and social mobility are the five main demographic processes that influence population dynamics and are studied in the field of demography.

questions.text: Which anti-TB drug causes red colour vision defects or optic neuropathy?( FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Ethambutol

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Ethambutol, an anti-TB drug, can cause optic neuropathy and red color vision defects, necessitating regular eye exams for patients on this medication.

questions.text: Identify the finding marked by the arrow in the below image: ( INICET Nov 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Vossius ring

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The Vossius ring is an important clinical marker of previous blunt trauma to the eye, characterized by pigment imprint from the iris on the lens surface, mirroring the size of the contracted pupil at the time of impact.

questions.text: A South Asian fruit farmer presented with fever, breathlessness, and encephalitis. What can be the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Nipah virus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Nipah virus should be considered when a patient, especially in South Asia, presents with fever, respiratory symptoms, and encephalitis, and has a history of exposure to fruit bats

questions.text: You discover that there is evidence of cardiac malformation in a fetus during a routine US scan at 16 weeks. What is the minimum level of fasting blood sugar at which you can suspect overt diabetes? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 126 mg/dL

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Overt diabetes in pregnancy is diagnosed with a fasting blood sugar level of ≥ 126 mg/dL, and maternal hyperglycemia.

questions.text: A 48-year-old smoker presents with yellow, copious, foul-smelling sputum that increases significantly in the morning after getting up and on changing posture. He has had this problem for a few years. What will be the first differential diagnosis? ( FMGE Jan 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Bronchiectasis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • The correct answer is bronchiectasis. The key features in this case include the presence of copious, foul-smelling sputum that increases significantly in the morning and with postural changes. These features are highly suggestive of bronchiectasis, a condition characterized by chronic dilation and infection of the bronchi. This leads to the production of large amounts of sputum, particularly after changes in posture due to the drainage of secretions from the dilated airways.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Asthma: Typically presents with wheezing, shortness of breath, and a dry or mildly productive cough. Asthma is diagnosed with spirometry, showing reversible airway obstruction.
  • • Option A. Asthma:
  • • Option B. Pneumonia: Usually presents acutely with fever, cough, and purulent sputum. It is less likely to cause symptoms that have persisted for years.
  • • Option B. Pneumonia:
  • • Option D. Lung cancer: May present with chronic cough and hemoptysis but is less likely to produce copious, foul-smelling sputum that increases with postural changes over several years.
  • • Option D. Lung cancer:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bronchiectasis should be considered in patients with chronic, copious, foul-smelling sputum that varies with posture, especially in the context of a history of smoking or recurrent respiratory infections. Recognizing these features can prompt appropriate diagnostic imaging, such as a CT scan showing characteristic tram-track or signet ring appearances.

questions.text: A middle aged female presents with headache. Radiological examination reveals a 2 cm mass attached to the dura. Which of the following will most likely be observed on histopathology? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Psammoma Bodies with Whirling

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Psammoma bodies with a whirling appearance are characteristic of meningiomas, a type of brain tumor that often arises from the dura.

questions.text: All of the following are the diagnostic criteria for preterm labor except? (INICET MAY 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: 4 contractions in 20 min and 8 contractions in 60 min with changes in cervix

questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Cervix posterior in position

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Preterm labor (PTL) is labor that occurs before the 37th week of gestation. Accurate diagnosis involves evaluating several key criteria:
  • • Contractions: At least one regular contraction every 10 minutes, or 4 contractions in 20 minutes, or 8 contractions in 60 minutes, with or without pain. Cervical Changes: Cervical dilation greater than 2 cm and more than 80% effacement are significant indicators of preterm labor.
  • • Contractions: At least one regular contraction every 10 minutes, or 4 contractions in 20 minutes, or 8 contractions in 60 minutes, with or without pain.
  • • Contractions:
  • • Cervical Changes: Cervical dilation greater than 2 cm and more than 80% effacement are significant indicators of preterm labor.
  • • Cervical Changes:
  • • The incorrect statement is Option D . A cervix that is posterior in position is not a diagnostic criterion for preterm labor. Instead, the cervix's position may be less relevant than its dilation and effacement in the diagnosis of preterm labor.
  • • Option D
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. 4 contractions in 20 min and 8 contractions in 60 min with changes in cervix: Correct. Regular contractions that meet the criteria of 4 in 20 minutes or 8 in 60 minutes, along with changes in the cervix, are used to diagnose preterm labor.
  • • Option A. 4 contractions in 20 min and 8 contractions in 60 min with changes in cervix:
  • • Option B. Cervical dilatation > 2 cm: Correct. Cervical dilation greater than 2 cm is a diagnostic criterion for preterm labor.
  • • Option B. Cervical dilatation > 2 cm:
  • • Option C. More than 80 percent effaced cervix: Correct. Cervical effacement greater than 80% is another diagnostic criterion for preterm labor.
  • • Option C. More than 80 percent effaced cervix:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The cervix being in a posterior position is not a diagnostic criterion for preterm labor. The diagnosis involves assessing contraction patterns and cervical changes such as dilation and effacement.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 366, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 366, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8 th edition

questions.text: Liver synthesizes all of the following except:(NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Immunoglobulins

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Immunoglobulins are produced by plasma cells.
  • • Essentially all the albumin and fibrinogen of the plasma proteins, as well as 50 to 80 per cent of the globulins, are formed in the liver. The remainder of the globulins are formed almost entirely in the lymphoid tissues. They are mainly the gamma globulins that constitute the antibodies used in the immune system.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Albumin : Exclusion, as albumin is a major protein synthesized by the liver, which is the most abundant protein in plasma, playing crucial roles in maintaining osmotic pressure and transporting substances such as drugs and hormones.
  • • Option A. Albumin
  • • Option B. Coagulation factors : Exclusion, as these are primarily produced by the liver, including factors such as prothrombin and fibrinogen.
  • • Option B. Coagulation factors
  • • Option C. Acute phase proteins : Exclusion, as the liver significantly ramps up production of these proteins in response to inflammation or infection (like C-reactive protein (CRP) and serum amyloid A (SAA), which play roles in modulating the immune response and inflammation).
  • • Option C. Acute phase proteins

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Common plasma proteins synthesized by the liver are:
  • ➤ Albumin Coagulation/clotting factors Acute-phase proteins Steroid binding and other hormone-binding proteins
  • ➤ Albumin
  • ➤ Coagulation/clotting factors
  • ➤ Acute-phase proteins
  • ➤ Steroid binding and other hormone-binding proteins

questions.text: Location of Bartholin cyst at the vaginal orifice is at? (FMGE JULY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

questions.text: Out of the options given below the most common habit-forming drug is? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Heroin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Common habit-forming drugs:
  • ➤ Cannabis Opioids Amphetamine and prescription stimulants Ecstasy Cocaine
  • ➤ Cannabis
  • ➤ Opioids
  • ➤ Amphetamine and prescription stimulants
  • ➤ Ecstasy
  • ➤ Cocaine
  • ➤ Heroin is the most common drug which is habit forming or in other words can cause physical dependence in which a patient gets withdrawal if he does not take the drug.

questions.text: Bilirubin is measured as mg/dl in which scale? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Continuous

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Bilirubin is measured in milligrams per decilitre (mg/dl), which is a continuous scale. Continuous quantitative data, where multiple values can exist between any two given values, is measured on a continuous or metric scale.
  • • Such as bilirubin levels of 4 mg/dl, 4.1 mg/dl, 4.25 mg/dl, 6 mg/dl, 7 mg/dl, 10 mg/dl, and 11.4 mg/dl, illustrate the continuous nature of the measurement, with numerous possible values between any two points.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Ordinal: T his option is incorrect because ordinal scales represent ordered categories or ranks. This is discrete data
  • • Option
  • • A. Ordinal: T
  • • Option B. Nominal: This option is incorrect because nominal scales represent categories or names without any inherent order or quantitative value. This is discrete data
  • • Option
  • • B. Nominal:
  • • Option C. Discrete: This option is incorrect because discrete scales involve counting or whole numbers, whereas bilirubin measurements can have fractional or decimal values.
  • • Option
  • • C. Discrete:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Bilirubin is measured in milligrams per decilitre (mg/dl), which falls under the continuous scale, as it allows for numerous possible values between any two given points, reflecting the precise quantitative nature of the measurement.

questions.text: Which of the following conditions would have the highest levels of ACTH and cortisol? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D. Cushing’s disease

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Cushing's disease specifically leads to elevated levels of both ACTH and cortisol due to an ACTH-secreting pituitary adenoma, distinguishing it from other conditions listed that involve different regulatory mechanisms of these hormones.

questions.text: Best test for the diagnosis of disease malaria species is: ( INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Thin smear with Giemsa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Thin smear with Giemsa stain is the best method for detailed malaria species identification due to its ability to highlight specific morphological features of the Plasmodium parasites.

questions.text: Which of the following drug used in ADHD is a Selective Norepinephrine Reuptake Inhibitor? (NEET PG 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Reboxetine

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Reboxetine is a selective norepinephrine reuptake inhibitor (NRI) that can be used off-label for ADHD, distinct from other ADHD medications that target both norepinephrine and dopamine or act on other neurotransmitter systems.

questions.text: All of the following statements about proto-oncogenes are true except? (AIIMS MAY 2021) BRCA1 is an oncogene. HER2neu is amplified only in a fraction of breast cancer. EGFR (+) is seen in non-small cell lung cancer. N-MYC is a tumor suppressor gene.
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ BRCA1 is a tumor suppressor gene and N-MYC is a proto-oncogene.
